alfredsnippet.snippet:
"There are various ways to understand the operation of the scientific community, including a search for truth, a puzzle-solving enterprise within paradigms (Kuhn, 1970), and a social enterprise in which scientists seek to enroll others, both humans and objects, to their own cause (Latour, 1987). To understand the response to dissenters, though, it is more useful to think of the scientific community in terms of 'interests' (Barnes, 1977). Company owners have an interest in making a profit, and scientists have an interest in publishing their papers and being recognized. 'Interests' can be thought of in terms of a stake in money, power, status, privilege, or other advantages. To talk of interests is to focus on the social organization of science ..."

(cont'd)
alfredsnippet.name: Phys.org Post - Scientific Community as a Collection of Interests - Part 1
